>>15133563
I think that the details of the process by which "consciousness" is "uploaded" are important in this case. Those are in quotes because I'm not sure that they are rigorously defined; what exactly is consciousness and what do we mean by uploading? For example, I had a thought experiment earlier about what the implications would be of theoretically training a massive artificial neural network model to replace someone's brain. This model would be like a black box and would respond to stimuli in the exact same way as the person it was trained on, its parameters being optimized on the subject's behavioral patterns and such. This new artificial brain would exist apart from the subject, and be more like a copy rather than a true transfer of consciousness, even if the model perfectly simulated the subject's behavior. More murky would be a scenario wherein part of the subject's brain is modeled and replaced in situ by an ANN, and becomes integrated in the person's daily life and routine. Then suppose further that progressively more parts of the subject's brain are replaced by functional ANNs that interface which each other, until ultimately there is no biological brain matter left. Assuming that the subject did not die at any point of this procedure, this might appear to be a true transfer or "upload" of "consciousness" to an artificial brain. Some schizo shit, nonetheless.

Since frequency = momentum and wave intensity = particle position, knowing both is fundamentally, theoretically impossible/meaningless, regardless of the fact that you have to slap atoms or photons into the thing you’re measuring in order to measure it.

Some results kind of dispute this. I mean you can find ways around it but it’s tricky.

>fire photons at a double slit
>at each branch of the double slit, add SPDCs, which send entangled idler photons off while sending copies of the original photons forward to a detection screen
>send the idler photons back toward a coincidence counter much farther away than the forward detector screen
>include a prism for combining idler photons so that which-path information is not recoverable

Do this and the photons on the detector screen produce an interference pattern

>remove the prism, so that instead idler photons hit one of two counters, allowing you to determine which path they travelled
Interference pattern disappears

>make the choice whether or not to include the combining prism AFTER the first photons have hit the detector screen, but before the idlers have completed their trip

Your post-measurement choice retroactively affects whether or not you see an interference pattern

That seems suspiciously tied to what you, as a conscious observer, can do to interpret the data, not simply to the “clumsy bludgeoning” of a pristine wavefunction experiencing decoherence when it bounces off a large, quantum-messy measurement apparatus

>>15128060

It all makes sense if you adopt the interpretation that wavefunctions do not collapse. When a photon hits a detector screen, what actually happens is it hits EVERY possible location. Each “possible” outcome represents an alternate timeline, an “adjacent history”, and they are all equally real. But you and I, as beings capable of experiencing only one “temporal axis” and not having the ability to percieve multiple simultaneous realities, are always one “random” selection from among that infinite continuum. What we see, therefore, is over time a random sampling of what we COULD see. So the fact that the wavefunction seems to be influenced by our observation of it is an artifact of how our observations are the only places where we are aware of our inability to view the entire picture.

If I had a device that could copy you completely, each copy of you would remember everything UP to the duplication event, and at the moment of duplication would believe HE was the real you, and the other was the copy. Now, suppose this copying device worked by two rooms; one red, one blue. Go into the blue room, take a seat, and a copy is created in the red room.

If I do this 100,000 times, and pick any random handful of “you”s to ask, they could compare notes and agree that it seemed like their sequence of “ended up in the red room” and “stayed in the blue room” was purely random. But what we know is, in fact, EVERY time you appeared in BOTH rooms, and it’s merely the fractured, limited nature of your experience of those events that makes it seem probabilistic.

Welcome to the Many Worlds Interpretation.

Heh, I would not expect actual "reversal" here yet but I got a rough idea what they achieved there. The "key" here likely lies in all the endogenous retroviruses (and other assorted transposable elements) in the genome of the mice (which also applies to humans). Can "blame evolution" for that, these parasitic genetic elements have acted like an accelerator for adaption due to two core features: being highly mobile within the genome once activated (and if still intact enough to reintegrate) and usually carrying strong gene promoters (usually controlled by cellular stress). Problem being, these sequences are still in most cases "parasitic junk" and get epigenetically silenced by default. Now some of them however carry a feature which in the case of a DNA double strand break (so DNA stress roughly speaking) prevents the silencing of their sequence after the chromatin has been "opened" for repair (this btw does play an active role in the terminal differentiation of some cell types) ... keeping them perpetually active and potentially disrupting, triggering further "control mechanisms" within the cell like senescence or apoptosis which contribute to aging. Or they trigger progressive genomic instability within the cell with similar outcome.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>15131352
We found a new (or atleast untill now unprouven) epigenetic marker, wich plays a key role in transposon activation and ageing.
Basically, this epigenetic marker is a transcriptional upregulator, and it tends to associate to untranslated regions. Most untranslated regions are transposons, some of which have transcriptional potential of endonucleases, and some have the potential to transpose, via copy and paste mechanism (or cut and paste, but those are more rarely intact).
Over all, the most important factor of ageing is probably transposos, and the largest problem with this, is they show such high polymorphism, that it's almost impossible to target them. But if we actually have discovered the global activating mechanism, we can target and silence transposons globally.
My boss asked me not to say much untill the paper is in print, lest we be scooped, but it's some really interesting stuff and it could be high impact. Unlike davids shit, we arn't just throwing shit at the wall. We are trying to figure out the mechanism of ageing.
This finding could be groundbreaking IF the transposon model of ageing is correct.
Or it could be significant but only a part of the puzzle if the synergy model of ageing is correct. In the later case, we will need quite a bit more time to solve ageing.
But to anyone out there who is curious, there is nothing in the theory i have found that would show that slowing or haulting the ageing process is impossible.

You are wellcome. I find a good starting point for any research is review articles, which will give you the nomenclature needed to search for whatever you find the most interesting, as well as giving a good framework to build on.

And finally a bit of a retrospective, but if you are interested in the genetic pathways that are involved in ageing: Kenyon, the genetics of ageing.
https://www.nature.com/articles/nature08980
I think they should all be up there for free.

>>15133633
those examples of superpositions are not equivalent to quantum superposition because they involve ensembles, whereas quantum superposition involves the superposition of a single particle.

quantum superposition is never observed according to quantum theory itself, as any superposed state collapses into a pure state by observation. and this is true; we have never observed a superposed *single* electron. in the double slit experiment, no single electron has ever been observed passing through both of the two slits at once.

if one wants to defend the reality of quantum superposition, one must explain how these superposed states transform into the pure states we actually observe. imo, it makes more sense to give up on the reality of quantum superposition.

>>15122071
Author-anon, you need a section about licensure as an engineer in the US.

-First Step

Set up your NCEES account.

https://ncees.org/

-Second Step

Take the goddamn FE exam, its best to take this right in your junior or senior year because its basically a comprehensive exam focusing on everything you've learned in undergrad, its an 8 hour marathon so come prepared. The key to passing is knowing how to CTRL-F through the digital handbook they give you. You can buy a hard copy of this handbook for study ahead of time

-Step 3

If you passed the FE easy, then IMMEDIATELY take the PE in your chosen discipline, its quite literally easier than the FE because its not as broad and only focuses on a specific topic. If the FE was hard for you, you might need to study more.

-Step 4

Get a job where you are working underneath another PE. This is the hardest part and it fucking sucks because you will likely be brought on at a lower salary and rode hard for long hours at a design firm (engineering sweatshop). You will also need to make friends with other PE's wherever you work so they will vouch for you. Minimum of three vouches and one "master" who will vouch for 4 years of XP as his apprentice.

-Step 5

Apply for licensure. Once you have the experiential requirements and the tests knocked out, you apply for licensure through NCEES to whatever state you are in. The license requirements do vary by state but there is reciprocity.

>Why the fuck should i do all this

Because those letters next to your name alone are worth a %20 salary increase. Stamping engineers are hard to come by, even harder to recruit once they've found a home. If you want to avoid doing businessman type things and stay on the technical side without bottle necking your career, then getting your license is your best bet

>>15122146
i only took the GRE general, so i can help with that.
>quantitative section
if you arent a braindead faggot, you should easily get 90% after going over the math problems for a week or probably less. they all follow the same format and are middle school or early highschool in difficulty. the easiest part to screw up on are misreading the graphs or the problems, but just take your time you have plenty of it for this section.
>verbal reasoning
harder due to the fact there's a huge list of vocabulary they want you to remember. it's been about 3years since i've taken it, but about one third to half of the questions in this section rely on knowing various vocabulary from the list. it can be a simple 'what is the definition of this word,' or 'what is a synonym for this word,' or a 'this is to that as this is to ???', or you may just stumble across it as part of the longer text readings, or many other formats. i went over the vocabulary list for a few hours a day for a couple weeks and got a nice score.
>analytical writing
the topics can range from easy to ballbreakingly tough and hard to decipher. if you look at a few different answers to the types of essays, you'll know how to easily format it, but the problem comes in trying to make arguments or form ideas for some of the most retarded topics that seem to come out of a random topic generator. i almost failed this section because i spent 80% of my time sitting in the chair, sweating my balls off, having no idea what to write. luckily, i had a revelation in the last 10 minutes, and i have decent typing speed, so it saved my ass and was my highest score out of every section somehow.

i cant remember exactly, but i think there are 2 essays at the very beginning, and then alternates between 2-3 sections of verbal reasoning and math with 1 verbal or quantitative section randomly being dropped.

sure thing anon, ill try to explain my experience as best as i can, dont know if itll help much but feel free to ask anything that wouldnt dox myself

basically last year i graduated with a bs in physics from my no name uni (even for my shithole standards) and got rejected from all my grad schools applications (all t100 unis). i realized grades werent enough, so i looked to gain experience in the 3 areas that i believe are most important for grad school:

1. research experience
2. teaching experience
3. professional experience

for the research experience, i volunteered to keep working with my bachelor thesis advisor and helped him with anything he needed, i helped one of his phd students with his work enough to gain coauthorship, and also we ended up expanding the work i did for my thesis and i presented this at a national congress for my area. felt retarded because i was the only one with a mere bs while everyone else had at least a msc but very good experience overall. another thing i did in this aspect was to create a research project for another congress for a student, basically tutored him through the whole thing.

for the teaching experience, its simple really: become a TA. Try to ask a professor you know/likes you from your uni since its easier, also helps with a recomendation later. in my uni TAs dont even exist lmao, so i did this "unoficially", with only my professor word as proof, but as long as you can put it in your cv its more than enough.

finally, for professional experience, try to get a job in something that at least loosely relates to your research interests. for example as i wanted to do ML in physics i looked for an ML related job. i know its very easy to just say "lol get a job lmao" but it really helps a lot. i had to sent 200+ applications to get mine, so keep hustling.

keep in mind that, besides my job, everything i did i did it for free. now i know how jannies feel like.

>>15128739
Having worked in the admissions office of a university, I can tell you that no one gives a shit about your GED score. All that matters is that you passed it. Your ACT/SAT score is something we paid attention to but your GED score is not a proxy for high school GPA. Some schools will ding you for having a GED instead of a high school diploma since they can't plug the GED into their formulas like they could your GPA. You're probably shut out of most of the best universities unless your a desired minority and can spin a good story about how you were oppressed and overcame it. But most regional schools will be open to you with a reasonable ACT/SAT score. Do well your first year or two of college and you can transfer to a better school if you wish.
Taking Michigan as an example, passing the GED, regardless of score, and getting a decent ACT score will get you into Eastern Michigan, Western Michigan, and Central Michigan but not the University of Michigan or Michigan Tech. Michigan State is in a weird state of flux right now and apparently have lowered their standard because they're hurting for money and need more students paying tuition. Your state probably has a similar roster of schools in a similar hierarchy.
One thing you absolutely positively don't want to do is fall into the for-profit trap. These schools spend most of their funds on marketing to convince people like you that state schools are going to turn you down but that they're willing to give you a chance (as long as you have student loan money). The quality of for-profit school is pretty bad, even those with regional accreditation. The costs are high because they know kids with student loan money don't care about the price. A local community college will be better than going to DeVry or the University of Phoenix.

community college can be risky for transferring some credits. a lot of the time (at least out of the people i know), they'll say that certain credits will transfer to the state university, but then when you get there, the credits don't actually transfer because the course content is a little different or theyre slightly different credit hours or etc etc.
if you can pay your way through/get free money through grants or scholarships, it might be easier to just take the state university route and not have to worry about certain credits transferring. if you're taking out loans, it might be worth the risk since most of the big credits (English/writing/math/some basic sciences/foreign languages/etc) should transfer easily and lessen your state uni time somewhat, but don't take too many electives/more niche subjects hoping they'll transfer to make your credits/time at the state uni significantly shorter. it's obviously your call in the end, so make the best decision for yourself.

>>15129869
California has the best process for transferring from CC to UC or CSU schools. Community college course catalogs note if a class will transfer to UC and/or CSU schools. The UC and CSU systems ahead of time make agreements with the CC system so the UC and CSU schools are obligated to allow credits in those courses to transfer. It's pretty straightforward though sometimes the CC will offer a class for more credit hours than the equivalent class at UC or CSU schools, so the extra credit hours just disappear when you transfer. Had this happen to me in another state where Calc I-IV were all five credit hour classes at the branch campus I attended but at the senior university I transferred to, Calc I-IV were only four hour classes, so while I had fulfilled my calculus requirements, four credit hours did disappear in the process.
Because someone will ask, my schools were on the quarter system, so Calculus was a four quarter sequence instead of a three semester sequence.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15133723
Fourier transforms (and the generic Laplace transform) I believe were originally made for EZ solving of seemingly hard differential equations. But their power has extended far beyond that. >>15133738 gives some examples, and I will say it also is used in understanding basic quantum mechanics, and one of it’s most useful application is through the Fast Fourier Transform - an algorithm that computes a Discrete Fourier transform with O(N logN) complexity.

The Fourier series is the intro to the transform, and the progression is as follows:
>series
They teach you about Taylor series to turm a function into a series of polynomials, your basis being x^0, x^1,…, etc. In the same way, you can describe some periodic function as a series with a basis of sin or cos.
>sine and cosine and Fourier trick
Sine series are odd, cosines are even, and for both the waves are periodic and extend to infinity. An important part taught at this stage is Fouriers Trick as a “sieve” to find the number in front of each term in the series, which is the same as finding “how much of this term is in this wave?”This is analogous to a dot product for vectors (if not, equivalent). Notice that the info the sieve tells u - a sort of ingredients list - is “equal” to the info of the original wave.

> combine and complex
Combine sines and cosines and you get almost any wave that’s periodic and extends to infinity. Figure out what the “sieve” is in this case using Fouriers trick. Notice that you can change the constants in the front, so ur basis is now e^iNx, and now you have the complex series. Find the “sieve“ for this one.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15133824
Cont.
> integral and fourier transform
What if the “wave” to be transformed has a wavelength of infinity? This is just a random function and need not be periodic (other constrains too). Instead of an infinite sum, take the complex series and turn it into an integral. Maybe call it a Fourier integral. What is the “sieve” this time? THAT is what is called the Fourier transform. Like always, the sieve filters out how much of this term is in the wave. For fourier analysis, the transform tells u how much of this frequency is in the original wave.

>You'll need a bit of math for regular expressions which come up very often when parsing strings.
Not sure about that one chief, but it depends on what you're doing with regex.
>Compared to most other engineering fields I'd say you need more math in CS.
Generally agreed. You need more math and less physics in CS (generally), whereas the opposite is true for engineering. There's a lot of natural, pretty difficult math in CS, but doing the absolute bare minimum with a computer requires nominally less structure than doing the bare minimum in engineering, so it gets a bad rep.
Also, it's a bit harder to appreciate the hard work in CS as opposed to the hard work in engineering since the problems a bit more abstract. Even if they don't understand induction stovetops, people can easily see how the effect of heating up your pots and pans without a direct heating surface is marvelous. It's harder to appreciate things like shattering dimensions in VC theory, or attacking flows on graphs using convexity and electrical flows (picrel).

I'm sure that as the public becomes more computer savvy and the problems get harder, we'll see people marveling at the ingenuity of advances in CS.

>>15130386
High levels of Hunter Gatherer DNA. Northern Europeans are predominantly pastoralist DNA, from the Yamnaya. Southern Europeans, mostly Farmer DNA from the Anatolians. Middle-Easterners, mostly farmer DNA from a mix of Anatolians, Natufians and Neolithic Iranians (depending on ethnicity). Indians on the other hand have really high levels of Hunter gatherer DNA in them, we call AASI (Ancient ancestral south Indian). Hunter gatherers tended to be swarthier everywhere, hence, any population descended moreso from a hunter gatherer will be darker, whereas those descended from the Pastoralists and Agriculturalists, both of whom developed lighter skin, will be lighter of skin. European have Western hunter gatherer DNA as well, but it's really low amounts so it doesn't matter much in their skin color.
It's really like a color palette, yes they have agriculturalist and pastoralist DNA as well, but the high AASI makes them darker. And the higher the AASI DNA, the darker they are, hence why lower castes and south Indians are darker and Northwest Indians and Pakis are lighter than the others on average.
General rule of thumb though, the more the melanin, the closer they are to ancient hunter gatherer populations.

>>15111645
a) [(n-1)(n-2)..(n-k+1)]^-1 * [(n-k)!]^-1
b) P = sum_k P(cycle containing 1 has length k) * (1 - [(n-1)*...*(n-k+1)]^-1)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15111645
Easy to do with straightforward counting arguments :

number of cycles containing 1 of length k:
(n - 1) ... (n - k + 1)
number of permutations of length (n-k) :
(n-k)!
thus number of permutations with a cycle of length k containing 1:
(n-k)! * (n-1) ... (n-k+1) = (n-1)!
number of total permutations:
n!
probability of getting cycle containing 1 to be of length k:
(n-1)!/n! = 1/n
Suppose 1 is in a cycle of length k. This cycle will contain k-1 other elements, there are (n-1) choose (k-1) ways to choose these elements (neglecting order, but this is fine). If we insist 2 is one of these elements, there become only (n-2) choose (k-2) ways. Hence the probability of this cycle containing k is :
[(n-2) choose (k-2)] / [(n-1) choose (k-1)] = (k-1) / (n-1).
Taking an average over k gives probability : n(n-1)/2n(n-1) = 1/2.

>>15129412
I have been reading about how the natural numbers are constructed lately, so just for fun and to check my understanding, I'll try to prove to you that n * (m + p) and that (n * m) * p = n * (m * p).

>Genesis 1-1: In the beginning, God created the integers.
I'll take the properties of addition (which can be derived from Peano's Axioms) as granted, to keep things simple. So here is what I'll do: define multiplication, and then, using induction, prove the properties you mentioned. The key idea is that when we say m * n, we mean "the sum of n parcels equal to m". More precisely, for every natural number m, let [math]f_m: \mathbb{N} \rightarrow \mathbb{N}[/math] be defined as [math]f_m(p) = p + m[/math] so that [math]m \cdot (n + 1) = (f_m)^n(m)[/math], where (f_m)^n is f_m iterated with itself n times. You might argue that this is just as arbitrary as the properties I am trying to prove, but I would disagree: the definition of m * (n + 1) is just the translation of "the sum of n+1 parcels equal to m" to the mathematical language.

Now with the definition of multiplication in mind, we see that [math]m\cdot n = (f_m)^{n-1}(m)[\math] and thus [math]m\cdot (n+1) = (f_m)((f_m)^{n-1}(m)) = (f_m)(m\cdot n) = m \cdot n + m[/math]. This is really the heart of the first property. Now, the proof is as follows: let X be the set of natural numbers p such that (m + n) * p = m * p + n * p for every natural number m, n. I already have proved that 1 is in X above. Then, suppose p is in X, we will prove that (p+1) is also in X:

[math]\begin{align}(m + n)\cdot(p + 1)&= (m+n)\cdot p + (m +n) \\&= m \cdot p + n \cdot p + m + n \\&= m \cdot p + m + n \cdot p + n \\&=m\cdot(p+1)+n\cdot(p+1) \end{align}[/math]

There, I used the hypothesis that p is in X and the addition properties. We can conclude, by induction, that X = N. So we have just proved the first property. Oh fuck, I am not proving the second one, fuck it, but it just as easy.

Look up Godel's incompleteness theorems. Any consistent formal system F within which a certain amount of elementary arithmetic can be carried out is incomplete; i.e., there are statements of the language of F which can neither be proved nor disproved in F and For any consistent system F within which a certain amount of elementary arithmetic can be carried out, the consistency of F cannot be proved in F itself. However arithmetic can be constructed from axioms that are obviously true and therefore consistent, for example that if equals are added to equals, the wholes are equal. Mathematical intuition is necessary to justify axioms.

Rotate the inner circle to find the peaks of high percentage, then focus on the highest one. >>15127272
Much of what we know about nutrition comes from the Minnesota Starvation Study. During WWII, conscientious objectors could fulfil their obligations to the nation without fighting in the war through alternative service. One of those alternative services was to participate in scientific studies like the Minnesota Starvation Study.
>A faction of the Civilian Public Service camps developed into a scientific research unit known as Camp #115, or the “Guinea pig units.” These units included around 500 conscientious objectors who volunteered to be scientific test subjects in a wide range of human medical experiments in the country’s top universities and hospitals.[40] The majority of these experiments were conducted under the direction and approval of the Office of Scientific Research and Development (OSRD), the Committee on Medical Research (CMR), and the Surgeon General at leading academic and medical institutions such as Harvard Medical School, Yale and Stanford Universities, and Massachusetts General Hospital. These experiments involved a range of research topics, including studying disease, survival in extreme conditions, and equipment testing. The experiments often endangered the health of the COs.
>The Minnesota Starvation Study was divided into four phases: A twelve-week baseline control phase; a 24-week starvation phase, causing each participant to lose an average of 25% of his pre-starvation body weight; and 2 recovery phases, in which various rehabilitative diets were tried. The first rehabilitative stage was restricted by eating 2,000–3,000 calories a day. The second rehab phase was unrestricted letting the subjects eat as much food as they would like.
These studies returned valuable data that no ethics board would allow during peacetime. So if you really want to know more about nutrition in humans, we need another war and a new set of studies with human Guinea pigs assigned to them.

>>15132322
It is thought that the 'little ice age',from 1303 to 1850, in England had a positive affect on the intelligence of Britons. The theory states that it created a harsher environment and thereby, increased selection pressures. Meaning, you would have to be more genetically fit to survive during such a time period (on average) than you would in say today's slightly warmer climate. Harsher selection pressure means a healthier populace and health and intelligence are inseparable qualities. In short, the weak and less intelligent would have not been able to reproduce as easily (keep their offspring alive and healthy) as the already genetically healthy and intelligent. The harsher the conditions are, the more this effect is seen. Its also a fairly ubiquitously accepted expalination, by evolutionary anthropologists, as to why northern Europeans have a higher iq than peoples from warmer climates. You need to think ahead and plan more to be able to survive in cold conditions than you do in a warm savannah of relative plenty.

>>15133815
In an ideal gas, temperature IS (proportional to, since it depends on the degrees of freedom of the individual molecules) the average kinetic energy of a molecule, and pressure is temperature times density (ideal gas law).

So temperature, in a sense, is specific pressure.

Because functionalists believe that what counts when it comes to consciousness is the causal relations and roles between its realizer, not what the innate nature of the realizer is. Functionalists are physicalists, or at the very least they're not dualists. There's some nuance, but the whole point of functionalism is that consciousness is not as mysterious as so many think it to be.

>>15131547
t. scientifically illiterate retard

NTA and I'm not an AI cultist or a soience worshipper, but you're assertion that we understand how all of those things work is simply false. Aerodynamics is an active area of research and even today we have very little understanding of the mathematical details of how flight works or how air turbulence works. I'm less knowledgeable about the other topics, but I'm sure there's still a lot we don't know about these other subjects. For instance, in color vision we still don't know whether vision is best described by an opponent-process theory, a trichromatic theory, or some other theory. The point here being that we don't need to understand something perfectly in order to make useful practical progress within that domain. Prehistoric farmers and ancient Roman architects certainly didn't understand biology or Newtonian physics, but they were still able to invent agriculture and deisgn buildings that could stand for thousands of years. This is not a "false equivalence" as you claim. The point, once again, is that we don't need to fully understand a physical domain in order to make practical technological progress within that domain. People were able to ferment alcohol without understanding how yeast convert carbs to alcohols during anaerobic respiration. Of course, AI technology would probably greatly benefit from a deeper understanding of human cognition, but that does not logically entail that progress in AI requires a complete understanding of the nature of human cognition.

I'm not especially interested in AI and I don't think we will have "human-level" AGI anytime soon, but the fact that we don't understand human cognition does not necessarily entail that we could created strong AI.

posts.com:
>>15128812
Problem lies in your interpretation of solution that was given, field E in solution is already combined field of both plates.
To see this calculate what is field given by one plate, Spoiler alert it is E=sigma/(2 epsilon). You are missing 1/2 in your expressions for Eplate.

If you are not certain how to obtain 1/2, when you apply Gauss law to the surface you envelop some area of plate with rectangle, but one side of the rectangle does not lie on the plate. Both sides are sticking out, one on the front and one at the back. for both sides you have EdS which combine. Even thou fields from front and the back are oriented differenty you also have that normal vectors of surfaces are in oposite directions aswell. This produces factor of 2.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15128947
Everything is positive.
If [math]b_n[/math] is bounded above, [math]\displaystyle \lim_{n \to \infty} a_n - b_n = \infty[/math] implies [math]\displaystyle \lim_{n \to \infty} \dfrac{a_n}{b_n} = \infty[/math].
If [math]b_n[/math] is bounded below, [math]\displaystyle \lim_{n \to \infty} \dfrac{a_n}{b_n} = \infty[/math] implies [math]\displaystyle \lim_{n \to \infty} a_n - b_n = \infty[/math]

its likely that you dont hear or feel things in dreams, or really even experience dreams at all. there was a phenomenon that occurred after television was first invented: previously in history, people had reported dreams being in color, but after television was widespread (and of course it was in black and white at first), people reported dreaming in grayscale. and then after color TV became the norm, people started reported dreaming in color again. this phenomenon is often cited as evidence that people dont experience dreams, they only remember them, and you brain fills in the details later as if they occurred in the past, but in reality your brain is creating them in real time. personally, anecdotally, ive had dreams where it feels like something (a person, a place, etc) is extremely familiar to me, as if ive known them my entire life, but in actuality are entirely novel. so personally im pretty susceptible to the idea that dreams fuck with your sense of time hardcore.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>15132375
>First, I don't know how that would even be possible given how tiny they are.
Actually it is possible to isolate viral particles by density in a centrifuge. You have to put the sample at the top of a column of fluids segregated into zones by density and it will arrange itself out. It's one of the standard procedures for viral isolation since the 50s at least.

This is how you get those really good pictures of well-studied viruses like influenza and smallpox.

oh god so much to write here, where to start...

ok, neurology first... ( and human development).

ok so our brains, have these nerves that go from the stem outward, called pyramidal neurons.. theyre kind of the main workhorse of our brains, when we're born we have wayyyyyy more than we do than when we're older..

there's a process happening throughout our lives called pruning, where basically our brains decide kind of by how much we're using them, which neurons to keep, and which we can do without (you do a lot of math at young age, you're not getting rid of the ones that are good at processing math)... also, at the same time, while pruning is going on, the ones that are being kept are having a process called synaptogensis going on, where basically theyre growing additional branches, getting more efficient, strong, etc...

ok so schizophrenia, lot of things can contribute to, but one of the big ones is like, you keep too many of the fantasy / sensory ones (or the ones involved there grew too many spines at synaptogensis)

ok so, also, as we're developing, the frontal lobe of our brain is growing (logic, future planning part of brain) theres a pathway there, mesolimbocortical pathway if you're a neurology nerd, stuff can go wrong there, that can contribute to schizophrenia.... multiple psychotic episodes, or really long ones, you can lose gray matter, can make it worse...

good news and bad news, if you catch it early, and stay on your meds, thats how you keep from losing gray matter, and the things that are contributing to the psychosis can be slowed to practically a halt... ignoring psychosis, or getting off meds cuz you think you're "better" is the worst way you can land at permanent untreatable psychosis...

longstory-short, get on meds, stay on meds* there is no "cure"

posts.com:
>>15129094
>Why are infinite products so much less talked about in math circles compared to infinite sums?
Because the theory of them is harder.
>What conditions would have to be true that an infinite product converges?
An infinite product
[eqn] \prod_{n=1}^\infty a_n[/eqn]
converges iff the the sequence of partial products [math]p_n := \prod_{k=1}^n a_k[/math] converges against a non-zero number. (An infinite product can't converge to zero. It can only diverge to zero!)

The best test for convergence is Pringsheim's test which requires you only to check convergence of infinite series.
Let [math](a_n)[/math] be a complex sequence with [math]a_n \neq -1[/math] for all [math]n[/math]. If there is a [math]N>1 [/math] such that all the series
[eqn] \sum_{n=1}^\infty a_n \\
\sum_{n=1}^\infty a_n^2 \\
\vdots \\
\sum_{k=1}^\infty a_n^{N-1} \\
\sum_{n=1}^\infty |a_n|^{N}
[/eqn]
converge then the infinite product
[eqn] \prod_{n=1}^\infty (1 + a_n)[/eqn]
converges too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It's worth noting that bar some niceness conditions

[math] \lim_{n\to\infty}a_n=a_M+\sum_{n=M}^\infty\left(\frac{a_{n+1}}{a_n}-1\right)\,a_n [/math]

so that

[math] \prod_{k=0}^\infty b_k = \sum_{n=0}^\infty(b_n-1)\,\prod_{k=0}^{n-1}b_k [/math]

Also

[math] \lim_{N\to\infty} \prod_{n=0}^{N-1} \left(1+\frac{x_n}{N}\right)=
\exp\left(\lim_{N\to\infty}\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=0}^{N-1}x_n\right) [/math]

There also is quite a bit theory for functions, like the Weierstrass factorization theorem.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15129094
>Why are infinite products so much less talked about in math circles compared to infinite sums?
>I also noticed that it is more difficult to get an infinite product to converge into something non-trivial (something other than zero, one or infinity)
I'm a midwit, so I don't know for sure, but haven't you answered your own question? Infinite products are probably more trivial and less interesting than infinite series. Series are also probably easier (since adding stuff is usually easier and more straightforward than multiplying stuff) so they get most of the attention at least in elementary mathematics (no idea whether infinite products are actually important in more advanced mathematics).
Series are also intimately related to integrals so that adds to their importance as well. Elementary transcendental functions can be easily expressed as infinite series, which in practice means you can think of them as polynomials of infinite degree, and since polynomials are easy to work with that makes series relevant even in that respect.
So it looks to me that infinite series are just easier and more readily applied to various problems compared to infinite products, hence why infinite products don't get a lot of attention. That's my two yen opinion on the matter at least.

Using Neutrino Vacuum Generators to Nullify the Insulatory Properties of Various Electrical Insulators to Achieve EMP-Like Damaging Effects to Infrastructure

We take for granted the static properties of materials in nature. Insulators, particularly, be they natural or artificial, bio-electrical, techno-electrical, or even thermal, are critical for a variety of artificial and natural systems to function properly. If the insulation around our nerves is worn away, it's called a demyelinating disease. If the insulation between transistors fails, a short is created and a computer chip may be temporarily or permanently corrupted. Since the physical properties of insulators are determined by the orientation of atoms and their electrons, most people do not worry that these insulators may suddenly cease to function reliably. The immutability of these materials, of course, is not a given. External magnetic fields, for example, can be used to enhance or block conduction. This begs the question: How can we go about using other external influences not to penetrate an insulator using brute force, but rather, to temporarily negate the intrinsic property of electrical insulation so as to cause the failure of the overall system?

No element of our electrical infrastructure; with the exception of electrical generating stations themselves; is more expensive nor time consuming to replace as electrical sub-stations.

To understand how the insulators found in sub-stations or in computer chips can be temporarily neutralized, one must first understand what is really going on within insulators that bestow upon them the ability to block electrical flow. There is no better way to understand insulators than to look at graphene, which is a perfect insulator when the flat side of the single-layer hexagonal structure is oriented toward the energy source and an efficient conductor when the edge is oriented toward the source.
posts.filename: Granholm (Sister, Can You Spare a Surge Protector)

posts.name: YWPTS

The reason for this duality is that, much like cylinders in a roller mechanism, their orientation determines their function. In a roller mechanism, the fact that one roller is behind the next helps packages on roller lines to be conveyed freely to their destination. Take those same two rollers and put one above the other and you have a mechanism for compressing dough.

In the case of graphene, the combined magnetic output of multiple (6) atoms of carbon serve, when acting as an insulator, to corral energy through the center of the hexagonal structure. At the center, the magnetic force is maximal and this intense force slows the flow of the energy. As an electron passed through the center of the graphene layer, the magnetism of electrons orbiting the carbons, poetically, much like the electrons in the NVG itself, diminish the neutrino contents of the electrons. Once an electron begins to emerge through the other side of the layer, its electrical and magnetic energy is mostly depleted and what is left of the particle is easily swept up in the orbit of carbon atoms and can lead to resonance events, occasionally leading to heating of an insulator. This duality of graphene's property of conduction/insulation is reflected on an easily-observable scale in graphite's dark, light-absorbing color and its concomitant capacity to glisten in exactly the right light.

Understanding this, if we could degrade the magnetic output of the electrons in such an insulator for even a brief moment, the insulator would cease to function as such and the result would be a catastrophic overload of the system.

>>15130438
I think big spheres in space is likely how we're going to build propellant depots in space, initially in low earth orbit and eventually everywhere. I envision filling up the depots will happen in 2 ways: 1: dedicated tankers. 2: excess capacity will always be filled with propellant (or materials for the prop depot). For example, if starship has a capacity of 150 tonnes, and is launching a 100 tonne satellite to LEO, the ship would fill the remaining 50 tonnes with propellant to top up the depot.

Spherical tanks would be best because they give the most volume per surface area. A way to make these would be to bring up lots of standardized sections (such as a bunch of triangles to make a 20-sided-die shape, an isocahedron). These triangle pieces would be welded by robot into the correct shape -- the robot would have multiple arms, some with electromagnets to hold the pieces at the correct angle while welding. After the isocahedron is assembled, it's filled with an incompressible fluid and a small explosive charge. The explosive is set off, popping out the steel into a perfect sphere. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=96yhdnhPxAw

The sphere could then be covered with additional layers for micrometeor protection-- could be overwrapped with fiberglass/carbon, or additional shells of welded steel.

Multiple spheres could be joined into one massive structure, at least one sphere per type of propellant. These spheres would be sandwiched between 2 parallel planes: the sun-side would have solar panels to shade the tanks and generate power. The shady side would have heat exchangers to keep the propellants cool.

There are several possible ways to pump the propellant. A system of this size can't easily use ullage burns, so spinning the tanks and collecting the fluid using centrifugal scoops might work. Another way would be to have a bellows that inflate inside the tank and squeeze the fluid out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15130848
And: how to stop leaks, specifically from micrometeorids?

One method is to have balloons filled with some kind of sealant in them, floating around inside the propellant tanks. If a leak happens, a balloon gets sucked to the hole and partially get sucked through, popping in the process. The balloon fabric plus the slimy sealant inside harden and seal the leak-- the hardening would be caused by exposure to hard vacuum, or exposure to the propellant.

Alternatively, the gap between layers of the concentric shells of the tank could be filled with a sealant, like self-sealing fuel tanks.

I don't think spinning the whole depot would be necessary or a good idea. If the method of tapping the propellant is with centrifugal force, then spinning the tanks individually would be superior to the whole depot spinning. You wouldn't need to worry about a wobbling/unbalanced massive torus if a tank is fuller than another. Another advantage to having the tanks themselves spinning is they could be spinning in different axes, so they'd essentially act as really big reaction control wheels, so you could rotate the depot using only electrical power.
Having the depot stationary would also make space walks FAR safer -- if an astronaut got flung off a spinning station, he would need a serious rocket with a lot of delta v to go rescue him. Compared to a fixed station where an accidentally untethered astronaut could get back with just a few m/s delta v in a small package like the MMU/SAFER.

Hoop stress around the equator of the sphere:
300m diameter
101000 N/m^2 pressure for air
thats pi*150^2 = 70700 m^2
101000 N/m^2 * 70700 m^2 = 7140700000 N = 7.1 * 10^9 N
lets use some steel thats 400 * 10^6 N/m^2 maximum strength
area of the hoop would have to be 7.1 * 10^9 N / (400 * 10^6 N/m^2) =17.75 m^2
strung around a 300m circumference 17.75 m^2 / (300 * pi) = 2mm thickness

hey, seems like the air pressure isn't an issue, on its own

These three constants drove the design: a shell of 8.05cm would hold the requisite pressure. Then I just figured out the mass of the shell and the mass of the propellants.

>>It would take ~829 starship trips to deliver all the steel
>>It would take ~223 starship trips to fill the tank with methane
>>It would take ~461 starship trips to fill the tank with oxygen

>>15133376
I could see using the moon to build the plates. The moon surface has a lot of useful materials: Alumina (Al2O3) is between 15% and 24% of the lunar surface. If you heat alumina up enough, it will release pure oxygen and you'll have pure aluminum. (On Earth we use a more complicated but far less energy-intensive process called the Hall-Heroult process, but that needs a lot of mass of reagents. Potentially it'd be cheaper to do direct smelting if building bigger power plants have less mass than the megatons of cryolite needed for the Hall-Heroult process). It might even be possible to bootstrap the system with solar furnaces -- use mirrors to convert alumina --> aluminum, use the aluminum to make more mirrors, etc.

I assume that the majority of the propellant depot would be oxygen, then methane, then water, and finally noble gasses [argon, krypton, xenon, etc.] for ion thrusters, etc. The reason oxygen is the most massive portion of the depot is because the stoichiometry of the chemical equation of burning methane:
>>CH4 + 2 O2 --> CO2 + 2 H2O
A mol of methane weighs 16g and a mol of oxygen weighs 32g, thus you need 64g oxygen per 16g methane (4 times as much mass of oxygen as methane). It's really handy that the moon has so much oxygen!

To get the aluminum plates (and oxygen) to the pressure tanks in LEO, you could use a really big mass driver (many km long). Potentially you could use the aluminum to precisely aerobrake/skip off the Earth's atmosphere to get to the station without using very much propellant.

>>15130968
>What is the answer to a question you haven't thought of yet?

It has become obvious to me that one could spend a lifetime dwelling on the implications of this question. The question seems to involve the possible limits of rational inquiry or perhaps even of determinism and completeness of systems ala godel. On a personal level, the question tickles my fancy for its seems a way of priming the subconscious pump. Given the possibility space of some topic, including those questions which are "just" outside your awareness, actively engaging in free association I get the sense of "firmness" or "relatedness" of some grouping of associations. From here I might ask what types of answers those questions may submit and what forms they take, and interestingly a sense of distance from what I know. The feeling is literally one of tickling or feeling a pull in a certain direction and contining to allow your thoughts to churn round that kernel. This all seems just an instance of the creative process in general; fumbling around in the dark until the proverbial lightbulb turns on. But nobody really knows from whence comes the creative impluse. In short, it boils down to Immersion, Ponder,...Profit. It's a mystery...It's a mystery. So, the relevance to your prompt could be the answer to the question, were you to receive a tool with no known purpose, to what extent would you appreiciate its usefulness or beauty? Would not the answer depend on how similar it is to what you already knew or could conjure from that possibility space? Is there some measure by which we could formalize when technology/ideas/forms proceed from the mundane to magic? Given the current and future state of AI, the question will need answering. Would a human be able to discern signal from noise in the creative fruits of AI; to decide what is good and bad, beautiful and ugly, nonsense or truth. cont.

Meditation thickens cortex, reduces anxiety, plenty of good stuff. Difficult to start but keep trying.
Anything that improves health will improve cognition, so work on sleep, hydration.
Cognition is highly linked to memory. This is easy to improve, by understanding indexing. When you remember things, consider the start and end of the experience or topic. If you recall the lyrics to a song, or the plot of a film, recall the first lyrics and the last lyrics, first scene and the last scene etc.
(don't do this with dreams, or you will get a massive headache.)

Besides raw intelligence, the most important traits required to become smart are curiosity and intellectual honesty.

The best results are produced by being motivated out of genuine interest in understanding. This means being honest with what you know and don't know, and spending time thinking and engaging with materials in an effort to find answers.

You become smart by having questions, and seeking answers. People with ulterior motives will always be inferior in their understanding, because they are not seeking knowledge. >>15123088
I just create studying materials, flash cards, summaries, tables, mind maps (Cmap is pretty good), whatever suits what I'm studying and how strong my interest in the topic is best. It's a lot more mechanical and straight forward than just reading through shit over and over again and allows me discrimate what information I think I'll want and be able to memorize in the long term, I treat it like mental sweatshop work. Once I get closer to the test, I'll just go through my study material and see if I can still make sense off it or if I have to read up on something again. I still cram for some subjects, but this way has worked pretty well for me since I can still get myself to sort through information even if I don't give a shit about memorizing any of them in the immediate future. Also helps with returning to subjects

If you get to perform a procedure/examination, ask people how they do it or if they have some tips or things to look out for, people do things differently and there's not necessarily a worse or better way, so look out for things that might work better for you, there are a lot of little things you can't really pick up from textbooks. If you're stressed or nervous during a procedure, take a breath and focus on going through it step by step, it's an obvious thing, but you can easily lose that focus if you're stressed.

In most medical textbooks IBS has max a couple of pages, sometimes it's just a page or two depending on how in depth the book goes. It's usually just explained as a "diagnosis of exclusion". In theory to diagnose IBS you have to do every other feasible GI test, including Colonoscopy with colon biopsy. You don't really study IBS in med school, you don't really learn about it in residency either.
But when a 45 year old obese woman shows up at your practice and tells you that she gets the shits and farts (leaving out the fact that she drinks a 1500 calorie milkshake from Starbucks almost daily and eats pretty much no raw vegetables ever), what is the most sensible thing to do?
Are you really going to send this patient to a GI doctor so they can shove a camera up her ass and take biopsies, which will turn out negative anyways? Or do you just diagnose it as IBS, tell her she has to fix her diet (she won't) and maybe take some Fiber supplements?
Then she will go on and annoy everyone how she suffers from IBS and that her shits and farts aren't her fault.
Don't confuse IBS and IBD though, the latter is a really serious disease.

All catalytic converters cause back pressure in the exhaust which reduces engine efficiency. Reduced efficiency means you have to run the engine harder to get the same amount of power out of it. Running the engine harder wears it out faster.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1. This isn't /sci/ related at all see >>>/o/
2. No.
3. No again. Emissions compliance reduces torque and available power but also reduces emissions. This has been known since day one. Society decided long ago that it was better to reduce emissions than increase diesel horsepower. This is especially true when diesel-electric trucks have more available power anyway, as their available torque is not governed by engine speed. This is why all heavy duty applications ie construction equipment, agricultural tractors, railroads and ships all moved to diesel-electric setups. Electric drivelines also allow for gensets, which do increase available torque, and have lower emissions than a comparably huge diesel motor anyway.

As for the "why", emissions devices slow the flow of exhaust out the engine. This slows the engine down and reduces power. Diesel trucks often do this intentionally through a jake brake as a means to brake the vehicle without applying the wheel braking system, which increases safety and reduces wear on the normal brake pads. This can also be done through shifting and, thanks to advances in automatic transmissions, is how most large trucks do it now as all large trucks come with automatic transmissions standard. Jake brakes are still often required by many companies anyway and many drivers just leave it on as it will automatically stop the truck if the driver does not touch the accelerator. Congress is about to require an equivalent device installed in all semi trucks very soon anyway, and it will also be illegal to tamper with those devices.

It is also illegal to tamper with EDLT systems required on trucks since 2020 anyway.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15132486
Can you see that there is a difference between 1 and 2 below?

1. One person takes off their exhaust.
2. A million people in the state of X take of their exhaust.

A single car not having an exhaust not causing a meaningful impact on air pollution doesn't imply that no amount of cars can effect air pollution.

It's sort of like how one person walking through the woods doesn't crease a trail, but if hundreds do it every weekend you get a well worn trail that will effect area erosion, etc. Or how a single apple in the woods will just degrade, but dump truck loads of apples will kill the native flora and leave you with a rotting swamp of apples.

It's the old philosophical problem of "a single grain of sand must be a heap."

yes because improved exhaust flow -> improved fuel flow -> improved fuel economy. This is especially true if the vehicle is starting and stopping a lot in an urban environment. Correspondingly, it's why cities like LA had such bad pollution resulting from this and why they began restricting it in the late sixties.

>>15121351
>underlying nature
The abstraction into sets with operations really is really getting away from the fundamental construction of a vector. Linear algebra is about is studying functions on a set [math] X [/math] that output real numbers, rational numbers, complex numbers, etc. Then because the output is a real, rational complex number, if you fix [math] x\in X [/math], and have suitably valued functions [math] f,g [/math] on [math] X [/math], then [math] f(x), g(x) [/math] are numbers of the given type and you can add them together [math] f(x) + g(x) [/math] to define function addition that is the function [math] f+g[/math] is defined by [math] (f+g)(x) = f(x) + g(x) [/math] and you can multiply [math] r\cdot f(x) [/math] to get another number so you can define the new function [math] rf [/math] by [math] (rf)(x) = rf(x) [/math]. And that's linear algebra. The abstract theory in fact is equivalent to just talking about functions with these two operations and all the theory around linear algebra can be derived from this perspective.

This perspective also yields a canonical basis, the characteristic functions [math] \chi_z [/math] for each [math] z\in X [/math] which are defined by: [math] \chi_z(x) = 0 [/math] if [math] x\not=z[/math] and [math] \chi_z(x) = 1 [/math] if [math] x=z[/math] and it is obvious that all functions are unique combinations of characteristic functions.

Finite dimensional vector spaces are just talking about functions on the first [math] n [/math] natural numbers, so [math] X = \{1,...n \} [/math]. So our vectors are represented by

[math] f = \begin{bmatrix} x_1\\ \vdot \\ x_n\end{bmatrix} [/math]

as we simply list the outputs in order with [math] x_1 = f(1),..., x_n = f(n) [/math], or [math] f= x_1 \chi_1 + ... + x_n \chi_n [/math] in our canonical basis.

posts.com: Because the gene is the fundamental unit of evolution, not the organism. The genes persist across organisms, and is replicated if it comes from one single organism or many generations of offspring. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15130007
The longer an organism lives, the more likely it is to get cancer. If you invented an organism that never aged, all the individuals would die from cancer eventually.

How fast your cells turn over (to repair injuries) determines your likelihood of getting cancer per year. More cell divisions = more chances to get cancer. But fewer cell divisions means slower or fewer types of repair. Humans don't regrow chopped off limbs because having that ability would confer more cancer than benefit.

Cells invented a way to make cancer rarer, which is to keep track of how many splits a cell line has done, and self-destruct if it goes over the limit. Every cell in your body essentially has a number of reproductions it can do which are going to last your whole life. Any group of cells that decides to reproduce uncontrollably will just hit the limit sooner and die without getting very large. In order for malignant cancer to happen, a single cell needs to randomly get two mutations at once: one to make it start splitting uncontrollably, and one to make it lose the self-destruct failsafe mechanism. This makes malignant cancer extremely rare compared to benign tumors (which happen constantly to everyone).

The natural lifespan is the result of an optimization of these variables: how fast do cells divide and how many times to we let them divide before they hit the limit and self-destruct. The rate and type of injuries that are common for this organism, and how frequently they die from random culling, and how frequently they die from avoidable causes, are all relevant to determining the optimal values.

That is actually an interesting question, with an interesting answer.
So we age, ou bodies become worse for the wear, and at the heart of it, is DNA damage accumulating, causing all kinds of cellular damage, which causes all kinds of DNA damage, untill we become completely unviable.
But what about offspring? How do our offspring start without the accumulated DNA damage? That is because the cells that make offspring, spermatocytes and oocytes are part of the so called germline, a lineage of cells which separates early on, and is under far stricter regulation and control for DNA damage, and they don't devide all over the place (which is a core source of damage).
So these cell lines make or kids. So what gives? Their protection. They can only be protected for so long, and therefore after a while, the offspring would not be viable. And at that point, evolution has no use for you. Disposeable soma theory of evolution and all that.
It is actually in interesting question, if we do manage to increase lifespan, will we also be able to increase how long we can create viable offspring? Current evidence suggests: no.
The greatest longevity increase we are currently capable of is in C. elegans, via modification of the HS metabolic pathway and the IGFsignalling. With this, we can achieve 20 fold lifespan in these little ringworms.
But their fertility actually decreases.

uranium
-------------------------------------
fuel rod
mixture of U-235 & U-238
U-235 5%
U-238 95%

when burning
U-235 --> breaks up
U-238 --> U-239 --> Np-239 --> Pu-239

when the U-235 share is only 0.3%
the fuel rod has been used up

waste storage: 10,000 years

As such, Pu-239 is used in nuclear weapons


thorium
-------------------------------------
Th-232 --> Th-233 --> Pa-233 --> U-233

U-233 is then used as fuel
there is no U-238 in the fuel => Pu-239 is not produced

when burning
U-233 --> U-232 --> Tl-208

waste storage: 300 years

U-233 can be used in nuclear weapons,
but only after it is separated from the U-232

We have prep chambers and load locks so we can transfer in and out samples without having to vent (we also have a UHV chamber on wheels that allows us to transfer from system to system all in UHV), bur if we have to make repairs we have to vent. >>15122720
For most elements, we use Knudsen Cells, which consist of a crucible, surrounded by a heating element. For high-temperature elements (Such as Vanadium, Tantalum, Niobium, etc) we use Electron Beam evaporators: a rod of source material is biased at ~3kV while a filament provides an electron source through thermionic emisssion

Whats the difference between TED and TEDx, exactly?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15126703
TED was started as an event for "thought leaders" to come together and share the latest in technology and design while enjoying some entertainment. TED stands for Technology Entertainment Design. It was a very exclusive event its first few years but eventually they started posting videos of the presentations online and gained a much larger audience. Being invited to give a TED Talk was a signal that you were considered the be a thought leader and what you said was important.
Because so many people wanted to give TED Talks, they licensed out the name to regional and topical events under the TEDx name, with a suffix for the area or topic. Events like TEDxMedical or TEDxSingapore took place, and initially the quality was near that of TED Talks. But then they started letting almost anyone who could pay the licensing fee to put on their own TEDx event and there was no real quality control over those events. Whoever the organizer wanted to invite was who got to speak at TEDx.
Sam Hyde famously lampooned this drop in quality with his '2070 Paradigm Shift' TEDx talk at TEDxDrexelU (worth noting: Drexel is where Lex Fridman was awarded all of his degrees).
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4jRoatZizQ0

Vaccine induced thrombocytopenic thrombosis was typically seen in the Astra-Zeneca vaccine. Still rare, with rates estimated between 1 in 50,000 to 1 in 200,000. They needed up having clots in unusual areas - such as the cerebral venous sinuses.

I assume you tested positive for ANA and anti-histone antibodies, which suggests a drug induced lupus (rare, but can occur with a variety of different medicines).

Haematological issues post mRNA vaccines were less common. Although, I work as a doctor and had a patient present with bone marrow failure post-vaccine, eventually dying from neutropenic sepsis.

The proteinuria is likely the result of kidney involvement of the lupus (lupus nephritis).

No doctor in this thread will be able to tell you with absolute certainty. But if you did test positive for antibodies suggestive of drug induced lupus, and the vaccine was the only novel medicine you had administered at the time, then it's likely that the vaccine was the cause.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15129817
Just as the starting point of linear algebra is the study of systems of linear equations
[eqn]\sum_{j=1}^n a_{ij}X_j = b+i,\quad i = 1,\dots,m[/eqn]
the starting point for algebraic geometry is the study of the solutions of systems of polynomial equations
[eqn]f_i(X_1,\dots,X_n)=0,\quad i=1,\dots,m, \quad f_i \in k[X_1, \dots,X_n][/eqn]
One immediate difference between linear equations and polynomial equations is that theorems for linear equations don't depend on which field [math]k[/math] you are working over, but those for polynomial equations depend on whether or not [math]k[/math] is algebraically closed.

A better description of algebraic geometry is that it is the study of polynomial functions and the spaces on which they are defined (algebraic varieties), just as topology is the study of continuous functions and the spaces on which they are defined (topological spaces).
Until the mid 1940s, algebraic geometry was concerned only with algebraic subvarieties of affine or projective space over algebraically closed fields. Then, in order to give substance to his proof of the congruence Riemann hypothesis for curves and abelian varieties, Weil was forced to develop a theory of algebraic geometry for « abstract » algebraic varieties over arbitrary fields, but his « foundations » are unsatisfactory in two major aspects. First and foremost, it lacks a sheaf theory, i.e., his method of patching together affine varieties to form abstract varieties is clumsy. Second, his definition of a variety over a base field [math]k[/math] is not intrinsic ; specifically, he fixes some large « universal » algebraically closed field [math]\Omega[/math] and defines an algebraic field over [math]k[/math] to be an algebraic variety over [math]\Omega[/math] together with a [math]k[/math]-structure.
In the late 1950s Grothendieck basically resolved all such difficulties by developing the theory of schemes.

>>15129014
In his Socratic dialogues Plato argues through Socrates that because the material world is changeable it is also unreliable. But Plato also believed that this is not the whole story. Behind this unreliable world of appearances is a world of permanence and reliability. Plato calls this more real (because permanent) world, the world of ‘Forms’ or ‘Ideas’ (eidos/idea in Greek). But what is a Platonic Form or Idea?

Take for example a perfect triangle, as it might be described by a mathematician. This would be a description of the Form or Idea of (a) Triangle. Plato says such Forms exist in an abstract state but independent of minds in their own realm. Considering this Idea of a perfect triangle, we might also be tempted to take pencil and paper and draw it. Our attempts will of course fall short. Plato would say that peoples’ attempts to recreate the Form will end up being a pale facsimile of the perfect Idea, just as everything in this world is an imperfect representation of its perfect Form. The Idea or Form of a triangle and the drawing we come up with is a way of comparing the perfect and imperfect. How good our drawing is will depend on our ability to recognise the Form of Triangle. Although no one has ever seen a perfect triangle, for Plato this is not a problem. If we can conceive the Idea or Form of a perfect triangle in our mind, then the Idea of Triangle must exist.

The Forms are not limited to geometry. According to Plato, for any conceivable thing or property there is a corresponding Form, a perfect example of that thing or property. The list is almost inexhaustible. Tree, House, Mountain, Man, Woman, Ship, Cloud, Horse, Dog, Table and Chair, would all be examples of putatively independently-existing abstract perfect Ideas.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15129014
Plato says that true and reliable knowledge rests only with those who can comprehend the true reality behind the world of everyday experience. In order to perceive the world of the Forms, individuals must undergo a difficult education. This is also true of Plato’s philosopher-kings, who are required to perceive the Form of Good(ness) in order to be well-informed rulers. We must be taught to recall this knowledge of the Forms, since it is already present in a person’s mind, due to their soul apparently having been in the world of the Forms before they were born. Someone wanting to do architecture, for example, would be required to recall knowledge of the Forms of Building, House, Brick, Tension, etc. The fact that this person may have absolutely no idea about building design is irrelevant. On this basis, if you can’t recall the necessary knowledge then you’re obviously not suited to be an architect, or a king. Not everyone is suited to be king in the same way as not everyone is suited to mathematics. Conversely, a very high standard in a particular trade suggests knowledge of its Forms. The majority of people cannot be educated about the nature of the Forms because the Forms cannot be discovered through education, only recalled.

To explain our relationship to the world of the Forms, in the Republic Plato uses the analogy of people who spend their whole lives living in a cave [see Allegory of the Cave]. All they ever see are shadows on the walls created by their campfire. Compared with the reality of the world of the Forms, real physical objects and events are analogous to being only shadows. Plato also takes the opportunity to use the cave analogy as a political statement. Only the people who have the ability to step out into the sunlight and see (recall) the true reality (the Forms) should rule.

>>15131607
VLSI relies heavily on the tools involved (ie Cadence) so I would suggest taking a course to get experience with them. It will involve a lot of transistor analysis to figure out propagation delays and power consumption. Prereqs would be more on your electronic circuits course and a little digital logic. In terms of texts our course used Digital Integrated Circuits by Rabaey, but I know Razavi is another big name in the field to learn from.
RTL Design is a little tougher to pin down, as its very broad. You got anything from computer architecture where you're designing CPUs to domain-specific hardware acceleration. This you can learn by playing around with FPGAs. Things like clock domain crossing, timing analysis, systolic arrays, benchtesting, and these days software-inspired design patterns are big topics.

because it answers one of the questions you posed in the OP
>Is there a science to the discourse of power that manages to break down any small group gaining a massive amount of power?
the reality is that this relationship to power is persistent throughout history and it’s often that “revolutions” are not fundamentally about changing the way power is used (because, Foucault argues, power is always used in exactly the same way) but rather who is wielding it and against whom is it being wielded. because power is bestowed upon individuals or groups through circumstances that are impossible to curtail (luck, heredity, opportunism, etc.) there’s no end to what Foucault calls “force relations”. sadly, Foucault doesn’t provide a solution to this problem (although he implies that there isn’t one to be found). this is just a human problem. human beings do not “develop” behaviorally the way we like to assume. they more or less remain children who simply follow what others do (or indirectly follow what others do if only to ensure they are doing the opposite). I’m not exempt from this (I could say I’m merely mimicking teachers who played a more important role than my own parents in my development), neither are you, neither is anybody.

after reading Foucault, my feeling is that people should be taught how to quickly recognize when they are benefitting from an imbalance of power and rectify the problem by desisting in its use, but when you think about the way living things tend to be naturally opportunistic, I grant that my feeling is a fantasy.

this role of power in human affairs is as inescapable as caste. we only overcome it superficially, but fundamentally the relationship never changes. and anyways “change” is an illusion brought about by a human inability to perceive more than three spatial dimensions

posts.com:
>>15130923
>can you give a summary of this?
>aside from the realisation of medicalised madness
>what's there to be done?
Foucault defines "power" in a unique way. Instead of considering typical political power - the threat of violence via police and military, Foucault coins the term "disciplinary power" which is roughly synonymous with "psychological manipulation". Foucault is particularly interested in a style of psychological manipulation based on interpersonal interrogation. One party is the "analyst" and the other party is the "subject". In such a situation, the analyst inevitably gains an ability to control and bully the subject. Foucault believes that this strategy for social power was developed by the Catholic church (e.g the Inquisition) and has now been repossessed by medicine and the social sciences. Moreover, Foucault believes that many ostensibly academic fields - "psychology", "criminology" and of course "psychiatry" - are a pretense of the implementation of disciplinary power. Essentially, Foucault is arguing that psychiatry doesn't really study anything; rather, it serves as an opportunity for people to put themselves into the role of "analysts" and manipulate "subjects". Foucault clarifies that he does not necessarily believe there is a organized conspiracy of psychiatrists manipulating the public - rather psychiatry functions as a "open strategy" for social power that individuals use to achieve dominance in their personal lives. As far as what should be done, it is necessary for us to distinguish which aspects of psychiatry (if any) are legitimate medical advice, and which aspects simply serve as a strategy for acquiring social power.

>Mach׳s principle as action-at-a-distance in GR: The causality question
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.shpsb.2014.09.004

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You are standing in a field looking at the stars. Your arms are resting freely at your side, and you see that the distant stars are not moving. Now start spinning. The stars are whirling around you and your arms are pulled away from your body. Why should your arms be pulled away when the stars are whirling? Why should they be dangling freely when the stars don't move?

Mach's principle says that this is not a coincidence—that there is a physical law that relates the motion of the distant stars to the local inertial frame. If you see all the stars whirling around you, Mach suggests that there is some physical law which would make it so you would feel a centrifugal force. There are a number of rival formulations of the principle, often stated in vague ways like "mass out there influences inertia here". A very general statement of Mach's principle is "local physical laws are determined by the large-scale structure of the universe".
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mach%27s_principle

Please hear me out, I am begging you.

Gravity is not a force that causes acceleration. It's an acceleration that causes force.
Space does not bend, it flows toward matter like water toward a drain.

As you are sitting in your chair (or wherever) you are accelerating at about 9.81m/s.
To illustrate this, imagine sitting in a dragster that is accelerating forward at 9.81m/s. You'd be forced into the back of the seat.
Now take the seat out of the dragster and set it on its back so it's facing the sky.
If you sit in it, you'll similarly be forced into the back of the seat as if you were accelerating into the sky.
From this thought experiment, it's apparent that we are actually accelerating away from Earth. And yet, we do not fly off into the sky.
The only reasonable explanation for this is that space itself must be accelerating toward earth to cancel out the acceleration

Imagine Earth like a big drain that space flows into. As space gets closer, it must accelerate due to being crowded into a smaller area.
We feel space accelerating past us toward the center of Earth, and perceive it as the force of gravity. There is no force, just acceleration through space.

What are the implications of this? Well it means we can simplify our model of the universe in at least one way.
Gravitational and kinetic time dilation are actually the same phenomenon.

As you know, time passes slower for objects in motion compared to a stationary observer.
For example, a clock on the ISS will run slower compared to one left stationary on the surface of Earth.
Time also passes more slowly for objects under the influence of relatively strong gravity.
A clock in Death Valley will run more slowly than one on Mt Everest due to the difference in gravity.

Again, space must flow faster as it gets closer to Earth due to being crowded into a smaller space (as with water down a drain).
So, in terms of movement through space, the Death Valley clock is actually moving faster than the the Mt Everest clock.
Therefore the difference in time is kinetic, not gravitational.

You can actually calculate the velocity of space as it flows past us by setting the equations for gravitational and kinetic velocity equal to each other and solving for velocity. What you get is that the velocity of space is the escape velocity at any given point.
