GR already does this. GR is an extension of SR that incorporates accelerating reference frames into the logic that governs inertial frames, and in so doing explains how gravity is just a form of acceleration (i.e. movement) like any other form of acceleration. They are, in a word, “equivalent”.

>It also suggests that gravity is an emergent property caused by the movement of space
Replace the phrase “movement of space” with the phrase “curvature of spacetime” and that’s already what it says on the tin. It’s one of those widely-known pop-sci facts that, “ball on a rubber sheet” metaphors to the contrary, most of what we experience as gravity has more to do with relative time curvature than spatial curvature; i.e. the “flow of space”, which is to say the fact that time is moving faster at your head than your feet, which is equivalent to space “flowing toward your feet”.

You haven’t really demonstrated anything here except a nice way of conceptualizing spacetime curvature. But it IS a nice way of doing that, in a lot of respects. One place the metaphor struggles is the concept of orbits; the idea that everything in freefall follows a (potentially curved) geodesic is kind of muddied by the image of space flowing past it laterally. It’d be interesting to see, say, the orbit of the Earth around the sun rendered in the context of the “space flows into the sun” metaphor.

>There is a strange contradiction among scientists: Science is supposedly about asking questions, except about scientists and how science is done.

Conceptualizing science as a social force that is founded on and as an expression of Western, Eurocentric values and as an extension of power allows for a critical examination of the very nature of science, its assumptions, and how knowledge gets defined and legitimated. A component of the historical and philosophical legacy of science is the belief in the primacy of European institutions, practices, and conceptual schemes to the exclusion of others (Harding, 1998). If science as a field reflects the institutionalization of dominant power structures, then Asian American women scientists, as reflected by the women in this study, manifest and personify these systems and power structures through the hierarchy in their identities, where some identities become privileged above others. This culture and environment not only diminishes the complexities and nuances of individual identities but also stifles epistemic inclusion. Thus, simultaneously unraveling and deconstructing the various threads of race, gender, and science allows a deeper, more nuanced exploration of science as it is currently defined and understood to reconceptualize science and weave these threads into new patterns, thereby redefining,revolutionizing, and transforming science at its core.

When I was in elementary school in the 1980s, I got in trouble for talking in class. The teacher gave me a long sentence to write 500 times as punishment homework. It was something like "I will not talk in Mrs. Smith's class while she is teaching us because it harms my ability to learn and the ability of other students to learn too." 10 FOR A = 1 TO 1000
20 LPRINT"I will not talk in Mrs. Smith's class while she is teaching us because it harms my ability to learn and the ability of other students to learn too."
30 NEXT A
She knew pretty much nothing about computers but when I handed her the stack of papers with the printout on it, I could see by the look on her face that she knew she'd been outwitted. Such fun.

>>15131180
Honestly, one of the best ways to learn math on your own is to learn to program it. Once you finish KA's Precalculus, you should pick up "Structure and Interpretation of Computer Programs" and "Structure and Interpretation of Classical Mechanics". SICM especially will whip your ability to think through abstract logic into shape, and will introduce you to a uniform starting point for lots of different categories of math. Once you're done, the way you'll find questions is by making your own after the same pattern of SICM: You'll decide on a subject in a field, study it for a while, make a little list of what you read about, and then try to code your own description of it from scratch. You'll be able to tell what you don't understand by what you can't code right, and the rest of the code will both reinforce your memory and provide you a reference to refer to down the line. Then you go back to the books, either to dive deeper or to branch out, and repeat the cycle. Infinite learning with finite technique.

posts.sub: What is the minimum number of Robot Masters do you need to beat before...
posts.com:
This is a question that I randomly thought of and it's been on my mind all day

Let's say you're playing a Mega Man Classic or X game and you don't know the weakness order. What is the minimum number of Robot Masters you have to defeat before you're guaranteed to have the weakness for the next Robot Master you choose?

Assumptions:
- Single, closed cycle of weakness
- Bosses only have one weakness
- All bosses are available (so none of the 4 + 4 split in MM8 or whatever Rockman and Forte did)
- There are no rematches
- We can say there are 8 bosses, but if you want to explain for n, even better

For the bonus question: what's the maximum number of Robot Masters can you beat and still not have a weakness for the others?

>>15130340
We can imagine a scenario where we pick the first boss who has the weakness for the last boss we pick. The second boss has the weakness of the first boss, the third boss has the weakness of the second boss, and so on up until the second to last boss. Thus, there exists an event where we "miss" the weakness of every boss except the last. Thus we can never be guaranteed to have the weakness of the next boss we choose, save for the last one.

posts.com: I remember a few years ago I decided to stop ignoring the climate change/global warming debate wholesale, and I wanted to learn the physics of their argument. Then I found that their models were based on redefining the emissivity constant of the atmosphere in the Stefan-Boltzmann law (radiative heat transfer) as a function of CO2 (so the atmosphere is more like a blackbody with higher CO2) in order to get their "dire" predictions. However, there was no data given to support modeling the emissivity as a function of CO2, so this seemed entirely contrived. Add to this the fact that prior to 2000, the prevailing theory of climate change was that it was driven by solar forcing and perturbations of the Earth's orbit about its nominal trajectory, which make much more sense and apparently were better models than whatever these "climate scientists" have come up with in the 2+ decades since then. All this on top of all the logical contradictions and blatant hypocrisy in "green" political policy, and I'm pretty sure it's all a huge scam.

>If you don't want to say human activity is the reason behind the warming, what is the more likely cause?
Human activity is related to climate change. However, It is not through an indirect fashion though. It's more through direct actions like oceanic pollution, large deadzones in the ocean from algea growth due to nitrogen fertilizer runoff, large swathes of land that are bare soil most of the year due to agriculture that reflect heat from the sun back into the atmosphere sometimes deterring possible rainfall events, deforestation for the primary purpose of manufacturing söybean oil for human consumption.
>but many are, and typically those are areas where a large number of people live. Record temperatures,
Record temperatures are not a big deal. Something as small as 0.1° over a previous high or below a previously set low is considered a "new record temperature." So this doesn't really mean much.
>forest fires,
Forest fires have occurred in many places historically fairly regularly. It's simply a result of too much underbrush crowding the land, becoming dry in the summer, and igniting in response to the heat. Some places in the American west have had regular fires for centuries long before the industrial era. For example, there had been fires regularly burning down the forests in Modoc National Park for millennia. The rate and effects of naturally occurring fires though can be minimized by proper forest management (something that has been lacking in the US in recent years). However, many forest fires these days are connected more often to human activity like intentionally starting fires to clear jungle as is the case in south America these days and some of the grass fires in oregon in the last few years or accidentally discharging of sparks due to some fault in some machinery like a trailer or a weed wacker.
>sea level rise
Hasn't happened.

Boston: "Mine is disconnected, and we are working with the auroral current. How do you receive my writing?"

Boston: "My current is very strong at times, and we can work better without the batteries, as the aurora seems to neutralize and augment our batteries alternately, making current too strong at times for our relay magnets. Suppose we work without batteries while we are affected by this trouble."

Portland: "Very well. Shall I go ahead with business?"

Boston: "Yes. Go ahead."

The conversation was carried on for around two hours using no battery power at all and working solely with the current induced by the aurora, the first time on record that more than a word or two was transmitted in such manner.

Louis pasteurs' various experiments are low tech and easily replicable. Petri dish procedures are simple and easy to perform if you want to select and examine specific individual microbial strains (mind you, only visual distinction is possible without additional and moderately priced equipment).

If you want to confirm or research transmission of pathogens on your own in Vivo experiments are necessary. Luckily you won't need to resort to animal experiments. You can use root vegetables to confirm transmission of mold transmission. If you feel up to it you can use insects to illustrate bacterial transmission. Just capture a few live flies, have them crawl around inside a Petri dish with a culture, then transfer them to a sterile growth plate and let them walk around for a few minutes and then let the growth medium cultivate a day or two.

These experiments, at the very least, would show you personally that germ theory is a good hypothesis. If you're serious in your critical approach, you can explore further experiments that require slightly more time and effort?
How's that sound? Could be worth the time to perform if you're truly skeptical right?

>>15125845
What happens inside the brain when people experience something? They learn something. Neurons create connections with other neurons and destroy connections with again other neurons. These connections are then myelinated to prevent them from being destroyed again. This is what creates your memories. When all your connections are myelinated learning becomes impossible and you get effectively amnesia as you can't form new memories. If a process was ever invented to reverse the myelination process it would be able to allow you to continue learning but it would come at the cost of wiping your previous memories, your personality. So either through death or through rejuvenation, the person you are will be dead.

posts.com: Anything you can learn on one side you can learn just as well on the other side with the same level of investment. If there's any intrinsic quality of "handedness" it's whatever caused you to start using that hand in the first place, but that could be the sum of a huge number of different factors.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15128339
I actually did my masters on this. Don't believe anyone who spins tall tales about creativity and whatnot, they are full of shit. Any significant differences are on a population level, they are slight, they are disputable and handedness isn't even a clear, binary concept, because it's task specific (what you have with writing and drums isn't uncommon). All I can predict from you being left-handed is that you have slightly better chance of being dyslexic than a right-handed person, stuff like that. You have a pretty good chance of being less efficient with language production, but don't sweat it: you need an elaborate setup to even detect this and the difference is less than 100ms. The anatomical difference is in lateralization: right handed people more commonly have language functions squarely in their left hemisphere, while lefties tend to have it more distributed. No, it won't affect your life in a meaningful way. Don't get me started on the whole left brain / right brain thing. that's horseshit too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15129658
>Anything you can learn on one side you can learn just as well on the other side with the same level of investment.
That's not really true. The use of the brain is different. Someone who is naturally left handed and forced to use their right hand will not have the same brain pattern as someone who is right hand dominant using their right hand. It gets even more complicated when getting into how left handed folks tend to split their language center between the left and right hemispheres, and sometimes have it in the right hemisphere entirely, whereas right handers have it disproportionately on the right side. Our brains are genuinely meant to be specialized.

Assuming 90% c travel possibility, that means travel time between alpha centauri to earth is ~ 7 years.

Lets reduce the speed down to 0.5c, that missile will have to go ~15 and half years.

If we drop the max speed to 0.1c (30,000 KM/s), then its a 90 year missile travel time.

Its possible, but depends on lot of factors.

>>15129948
From another thread, about building orbital depots:
I think big spheres in space is likely how we're going to build propellant depots in space, initially in low earth orbit and eventually everywhere. I envision filling up the depots will happen in 2 ways: 1: dedicated tankers. 2: excess capacity will always be filled with propellant (or materials for the prop depot). For example, if starship has a capacity of 150 tonnes, and is launching a 100 tonne satellite to LEO, the ship would fill the remaining 50 tonnes with propellant to top up the depot.

Spherical tanks would be best because they give the most volume per surface area. A way to make these would be to bring up lots of standardized sections (such as a bunch of triangles to make a 20-sided-die shape, an isocahedron). These triangle pieces would be welded by robot into the correct shape -- the robot would have multiple arms, some with electromagnets to hold the pieces at the correct angle while welding. After the isocahedron is assembled, it's filled with an incompressible fluid and a small explosive charge. The explosive is set off, popping out the steel into a perfect sphere. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=96yhdnhPxAw [Embed]

The sphere could then be covered with additional layers for micrometeor protection-- could be overwrapped with fiberglass/carbon, or additional shells of welded steel.

Multiple spheres could be joined into one massive structure, at least one sphere per type of propellant. These spheres would be sandwiched between 2 parallel planes: the sun-side would have solar panels to shade the tanks and generate power. The shady side would have heat exchangers to keep the propellants cool.

There are several possible ways to pump the propellant. A system of this size can't easily use ullage burns, so spinning the tanks and collecting the fluid using centrifugal scoops might work. Another way would be to have a bellows that inflate inside the tank and squeeze the fluid out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15130886
And: how to stop leaks, specifically from micrometeoroids?

One method is to have balloons filled with some kind of sealant in them, floating around inside the propellant tanks. If a leak happens, a balloon gets sucked to the hole and partially get sucked through, popping in the process. The balloon fabric plus the slimy sealant inside harden and seal the leak-- the hardening would be caused by exposure to hard vacuum, or exposure to the propellant.

Alternatively, the gap between layers of the concentric shells of the tank could be filled with a sealant, like self-sealing fuel tanks.

I don't think spinning the whole depot would be necessary or a good idea. If the method of tapping the propellant is with centrifugal force, then spinning the tanks individually would be superior to the whole depot spinning. You wouldn't need to worry about a wobbling/unbalanced massive torus if a tank is fuller than another. Another advantage to having the tanks themselves spinning is they could be spinning in different axes, so they'd essentially act as really big reaction control wheels, so you could rotate the depot using only electrical power.
Having the depot stationary would also make space walks FAR safer -- if an astronaut got flung off a spinning station, he would need a serious rocket with a lot of delta v to go rescue him. Compared to a fixed station where an accidentally untethered astronaut could get back with just a few m/s delta v in a small package like the MMU/SAFER.

>Japanese scientists and origami masters considered in 2008 launching a flotilla of paper planes from space.[2] The launch was tentatively slated for 2009[3] from the International Space Station[4] 250 miles above Earth. However, the planes' developers, Takuo Toda (see paper plane world records) and fellow enthusiast Shinji Suzuki, an aeronautical engineer and professor at Tokyo University, postponed the attempt after acknowledging it would be all but impossible to track the planes during their week-long journey to Earth, assuming any of them survived the searing descent. The developers continue, in 2009, with hopes that China or Russia will back further efforts on the project
>Some 30[4] to 100[5] planes had been considered to make the descent, each gliding downward over what was expected to be the course of a week to several months. If one of the planes survived to Earth, it would have made the longest flight ever by a paper plane, traversing the 250 mi./400 km. vertical descent. In a test in Japan in February 2008, a prototype about 2.8 inches long and 2 inches wide survived Mach 7 speeds and temperatures reported to be 200°C in a hypersonic wind tunnel for 10 seconds. Materials designed for use in conventional reentry vehicles, including ceramic composites, withstand temperatures on the order of 2200°C.[6] The 30 cm planes were to have been made from heat-resistant paper treated with silicon.

>>15132423
If you're not American or Chinese you've got some options:

Kourou isn't bad if you can actually get a flight out into the jungle. If you're not on the VIP viewing deck you might have a bad time though, considering how often CSG is overcast.

Tanegashima is less out of the way but is by all accounts a gorgeous place to visit, rockets or no. There's plenty of good place to watch a launch from if Japan decides that it's going to be launching any rockets that year. Good news! Japan has decided they will launch rockets this year.

I've got no clue what the overall conditions are like at Satish Dhawan, but apparently the ISRO opened a viewing center with five thousand seat bleachers before the lockdowns, so there's a great opportunity to sit down enjoy a PSLV launch while crowded in with all the boys.

If you're Scandinavian there's the Andøya and Esrange Space Centers, but those are just suborbital sites with unrealized ambitions so far, which puts them in the same category as SaxaVord and Sutherland. Maybe something this year, but if not there's always sounding rockets.

If you're Austrailian there's the dim hope that something might someday launch from the Whalers Way Orbital Launch Complex, but that's getting tag-teamed by the triple threat of lethargic government bureaucracy, Nimby environmentalism and Hawaiian-tier native activism. Species threatened by the site include the southern emu wren and white-bellied whipbird, although there is no mention of any beetles.

It was actually because the engineers were paranoid about the landing gear deploying before reentry. There wasn't any way to retract the gear or close the doors so if they popped out early while the shuttle was in orbit there wouldn't have been any way to save the multi-billion dollar spacecraft.

>>15133370
The Atlas and Delta lines were killed off and their payloads moved over to the shuttle because Congress refused to fund a space station project. Without space station assembly flights the shuttle's launch cadence was going to be minimal and the per launch costs would have been even more absurd than they ended up being. Putting everything onto the shuttle was a desperate attempt to deliver on the shuttle being "cheap access to space."

posts.name: Anonymous

>>15119684
It's a catch 22. College is a huge financial investment, but then without it, you stand to earn FAR less money over the course of your lifetime than if you have one.

For example, going to Law school for 3 years at a top 50 Law school in America will put you 200-300k in debt, easy. But then we're to remark, if you are top 20% of your class at those schools, you are likely to be recruited by a top law firm or corporate law division where the starting salary is usually around 160,00k, sometimes more if you've internshipped and networked well during your summers.

So 300k sounds like a ton. 3-5 years working at a top firm with that investment, you will have paid off all of it. My friend graduated from Georgetown Law Center in 2020, I don't know where he was ranked in his class, but he was recruited by JP Morgan. He makes 220,000 a year there, and he has already paid off his $280,000 student loans in two years. He is currently looking for work in the tech world at big tech companies, Google, Apple, Facebook, etc, has several interviews already for them. He'll probably secure a job at one of them in the coming weeks, and move to California, making the same money or more, no debt, and only green pastures ahead.

A Law degree is a huge investment, but once you have it, it is a Golden Ticket. Lawyers run Movie studios, Baseball teams, work in politics, finance, hold top positions at Universities, etc. IMO a JD degree is the best degree to get right now if, first of all, you like law and reasoning, but second if you are personable, pleasent, and have some level of charm about you, and are able to market your abilities relative to the degree discipline. Law covers Philosophy, reasoning, Literature, Latin, Greek, you are well versed in the legal code in most every discipline. It's the only degree I can justify someone investing for right now, even ahead of Doctors.

>Abstract: A corollary of the Simulation Argument is that the universe’s computational capacity may be limited. This game-theoretical equilibrium could be interpreted as the “katechon” – that which withholds eschaton – doom, oblivion, the end of the world. Depends on what you want to work with. You can do some interesting shit with just a centrifuge, some DNA extraction kits, a PCR machine and a gel electorphoresis setup, along with an incubator a heatblock and a fridge, and an autoclave. These will alow you to do some fun stuff with C. elegans, E. coli and their DNA.
The thing is, reagents are expensive too.
If you wanted to go one step further, you could invest in a minion system.
All of the above costs in the few thousand dollar range. maybe 10-20k would get you a fun little lab. Nothing serious, but enough to do some meaningfull work.

>>15128600 (OP)
>Can science help me go back to 2018 and undo my mistakes?

backwards time travel where the traveler can make changes to the past which affect the future is impossible.Time is our movement through another spacial dimension. Atoms exist only in one place and time at a time. The past is where these atoms were. You can go really fast and "catch up" with the current present atoms in the future but the atoms are not yet in the future.

To go to the past and make changes can't happen because all the atoms in our past are busy being here in the present right now. They are not both in the past and in the present at the same time. If you "went to the past" you would be there alone with only the atoms you brought with you.

it's very simple, now people can stop with the paradox discussions because time travel paradoxes can never happen in the first place
